Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: A Social and Data-Driven Platform for Searching Healthcare Providers
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project results from it providing a novel way to more effectively match patients to healthcare providers. Patients will be able to use the developed system to discover and compare the most suitable and experienced healthcare providers for their unique health needs, instead of just viewing a directory of providers in their area. For example, the proposed system will recommend to a patient searching for "knee replacement surgery" orthopedic surgeons with experience in this or similar procedures, positive health outcomes and high past patients satisfaction levels. The patient may then compare these surgeons by expertise, relative cost, location and several other attributes. By helping patients select the best healthcare providers, the proposed system not only has the potential to improve health outcomes, because providers will see the patients more relevant to their expertise, but may also reduce the number of "shopping-around" visits which may lead to a reduction in overall healthcare costs.

This Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project will study methods to exploit Big Data, ranging from government-published health metrics and surveys to public social media data, to better match patients to healthcare providers. A key challenge is that many of these sources include free text, which must be analyzed to extract medically significant information. Further, different sources refer to the same medical terms in different ways; for example "myocardial infarction" vs. "heart attack", or "doctor knows her stuff" vs. "doctor is knowledgeable". Data mining and artificial intelligence techniques will be leveraged to identify which provider properties - medical school, years of experience, affiliated hospitals, and so on - should be used when searching for providers and how these properties should be best weighted and combined, given the healthcare needs of a patient.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant generated the knowledge to build an effective healthcare provider search interface, and a working prototype of this system, available at http://smartdocfinder.com. In this search interface, the user inputs a location (which may be automatically detected), optionally a specialty from a drop-down box, and optionally a short textual description of her health condition (e.g., “swollen knee”). Then, the system ranks all healthcare providers in the area based on their estimated care quality for the user-specified condition, using a comprehensive set of factors including but not limited to: (i) the provider’s credentials like year of graduation and affiliated hospitals, (ii) public performance datasets, and (iii) patient reviews.

The key market of such a system is the people that either do not already have providers capable of satisfying their healthcare needs, or are dissatisfied with their current providers. Current systems for searching for physicians can be viewed as catalogs of physicians, where users may search by location, specialty, insurance or reviews score. A couple of them also provide basic query-independent ranking of physicians based on attributes like average reviews rating, medical school or affiliated hospitals.

The intellectual property of this work includes the following: (i) Novel methods to analyze the content of patient reviews; (ii) Effective methods to combine multiple attributes of providers, such as years of experience and residency hospital, into a provider score; (iii) Methods to personalize the ranking based on the unique patient needs.

The broader impact of this work consists of the potential empowerment of patients to select the right healthcare providers, which is challenging given the sparsity of available data and the complexity of parsing much of this data by non-medical experts. Further, SmartDocFinder is located in Riverside, CA, which is an economically disadvantaged area.


Last Modified: 09/21/2016
Modified by: Evangelos Christidis
